awd_titl_txt: Dynamic Thermal Physiology of Host-Parasite Interactions
awd_abstract_narration: Climate change and pandemic disease are two of the most daunting challenges of the twenty-first century. In this new era with the potential for increased temperatures and climate variability, controlling the spread of infectious diseases will require a deep understanding of how climate variation influences parasitic diseases. Most studies of climate-disease interactions have focused on mean temperature and precipitation, ignoring short-term climate fluctuations. This approach assumes that neither parasites nor their hosts acclimate to temperature shifts, despite evidence that such acclimation responses are pervasive in ectothermic hosts. Accounting for these acclimation responses could dramatically alter predictions of climate-disease models, particularly for diseases with ectothermic hosts and vectors (e.g., malaria). However, there is currently no quantitative theory describing parasite and host acclimation responses to temperature shifts. Johnson and his colleagues will fill this important gap in knowledge by (1) developing a mathematical model describing how temperature variability influences parasitic infection, (2) parameterizing this model in a trematode-tadpole system using a series of controlled temperature experiments, and (3) testing quantitative predictions of the model across different timescales of temperature variability in artificial ponds. Their central hypothesis is that parasites acclimate to temperature changes more rapidly than their hosts because of their smaller sizes and faster metabolisms, leading to higher infection rates under variable-temperature conditions. This project will also train undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral research scholars and promote science awareness through public outreach and workshops for K-12 teachers.

por.por_cntn:
Available forecasts suggest that climate change will involve alterations in both mean temperature and temperature variability. These changes are especially important for cold-blooded animals like amphibians, many of which are threatened by climate-related parasitic diseases. Prior to our study, relatively little was known about how ectothermic hosts and their parasites respond to fluctuating-temperature conditions. In particular, existing predictive models ignored the potential for acclimation responses of hosts and their parasites following shifts to new temperatures.

In our project, we tackled this knowledge gap by studying how temperature shifts influence tadpole infection by Ribeiroia ondatrae, a snail-borne trematode parasite best known for causing leg deformities in amphibians. Our goals were to (1) develop a theoretical model describing how temperature shifts influence parasitism in ectotherms, incorporating lags in host and parasite acclimation responses, (2) parameterize the model through a series of controlled-temperature laboratory experiments, (3) test model predictions with a large-scale mesocosm experiment, and (4) develop a public outreach program to K-12 teachers focusing on controversial topics in Biology education. This project has so far generated 15 papers in peer-reviewed journals, one book chapter, and 10 presentations at national or international conferences.

Our first major achievement was publishing a new theoretical framework to describe the temperature-dependence of host-parasite interactions in fluctuating-temperature environments (Rohr et al. 2013, Conservation Physiology). Our framework, based on Meabolic Theory, uses separate equations to describe the temperature-dependence of parasite infectivity and host resistance to infection. Each of these processes is described using equations typically used to describe the temperature-dependence of enzyme reaction rates. This framework has substantial benefits: (1) providing a more mechanistic framework to describe temperature-dependence of parasite infectivity and host resistance, (2) promising more generality of conclusions across taxonomic groups, (3) providing a mechanistic framework for modeling acclimation effects, and (4) potentially allowing us to estimate key model parameters by measuring temperature-dependence of metabolic proxies like host respiration. We have since applied this framework to describe the temperature-dependence of R. ondatrae production by snails and R. ondatrae infection rates in tadpoles, using data from the proposed laboratory experiments.

A second major achievement was developing a new fluorescent-dye technique to count and track survival of encysted parasites in live tadpoles (LaFonte et al. 2013, 2015). This technique is exciting because it allowed us to confirm that tadpoles can kill and destroy encysted trematode parasites, and to track changes in clearance rates through time.

A third major achievement was completing the proposed laboratory experiments, in which we measured the effects of temperature and thermal acclimation on (1) production of parasite infective stages (cercariae) by infected snails and (2) parasite encystment and clearance rates in tadpoles. We also estimated the time it takes tadpoles to acclimate to a new temperature, using our new fluorescent-dye technique to track changes in cyst clearance rates through time (Altman et al. in review). To ensure true replication of our temperature treatments, we utilized a novel experimental setup comprised of 50 custom-built incubators, as described by Raffel et al. (2013, Nature Climate Change).
